<p>Okay, lovely people, this is huge for me. I’m actually in the midst of writing a<br> book. It’s called “<a href="https://www.manning.com/books/front-end-tooling-with-gulp-bower-and-yeoman/?a_aid=fettblog&amp;a_bid=238ac06a">Front-End Tooling with Gulp, Bower and Yeoman</a>”, and it’s<br> – you guessed it – about front-end tooling with Gulp, Bower and Yeoman. Actually<br> I’ve been writing on it for the last 9 months, and now it has reached the phase of<br> going public for the first time. It’s in the so called “Early Access Program” from<br> Manning (MEAP), where you can buy it before it goes to print, helping me pointing at<br> all the mistakes I make. Or do some slap on the back because it’s so good.</p> <blockquote> <p>It’s a huge step for me, but a small MEAP for mankind.</p> <ul> <li>Lance Armstrong</li> </ul> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>There’s a voucher code for 50% off below</p> <ul> <li>That marketing lady</li> </ul> </blockquote> <p>I tend to call my book “FETT”, because it’s the name of the blog. It that case, it stands<br> for “Front-End Tooling Talk”. I’ve written and talked a lot about<br> different tools for Front-End developers in the last few years, so some guys thought it might be a good<br> idea to turn those thoughts into a book. So here are the learnings that I made<br> at my time at Netural and my current employment at <a href="http://ruxit.com">Ruxit</a>.</p> <p>But why those three tools?</p> <h2>Gulp</h2> <p>So, here’s the thing: I won’t do that stereotypical things with you every Gulp<br> course tries to do. The ever-repetitive “If you want to build this, use that<br> plugin. And if you want to use that, use this plugin” mantra you see over and<br> over again. So many people have shown you how there Gulpfile looks like and that’s<br> absolutely fine. Because you can learn a lot from them.</p> <p>But you wouldn’t need a book telling you the same. This is where the Gulp part<br> from “FETT” differs: You will learn how Gulp and streams work underneath.</p> <p>You will learn that Gulp is basically a collection of other tools combined<br> under one graspable API. That it uses streams and virtual file systems.<br> And you will learn not only how super awesome this is to use, but also where<br> the catch is when you want to combine it with other things.</p> <p>I will spend a good deal of time showing you the wonderful art<br> of pipeline crafting. You can do so much with stream arrays, incremental builds,<br> pipe snippets, merged streams, etc. that really helps your special use cases.<br> You will also learn when to extend Gulp and when to just let it be.</p> <p>As for which<br> plugin will compile Sass for you or PostCSS or React or whatever, you will figure<br> that out on your own. Here you will learn <em>why</em> a <code>gulp-ruby-sass</code> behaves a tad<br> different from <code>gulp-sass</code>, and how you can combine it with un-Sass-y things.</p> <div class="center"> ![Ancient swordsman says: Do a build pipeline](/wp-content/uploads/2015/fett-meap.jpg) </div> So that's pretty advanced stuff for Gulp, but it always burns down to a common denominator all build tools have: Getting your stuff processed to have some great result in the end. Heck, we even used Grunt at some point, but then decided that Gulp would be a more fitting technology because of its flexibility. And to be honest: It's a lot more fun. <h2>Bower</h2> <p>The same thing is going on with Bower. It’s pretty boring to learn how to install<br> stuff. It’s more fun knowing what dependency trees are and what you have to keep<br> an eye on when creating new components. Those learnings are directly transferrable<br> to every other package manager out there. Want to use NPM instead of Bower? Same<br> chapters work for you, because your knowledge will be universal (JavaScript, buzzword-bombing).</p> <h2>Yeoman</h2> <p>The last one. This tool is actually the thing that got me here in the first place,<br> as it brings the whole workflow of building pipelines, dependency managers and<br> project templates to a full circle. <a href="http://fettblog.eu/introduction-to-yeoman-slides/">Yeoman</a> helped our Front-End team keeping project<br> standards fresh and exciting for all our 10 developers. And again, since installing<br> and using generators is pretty boring to teach, you will learn how to create your own generator.</p> <h2>A modern workflow for the modern developer</h2> <p>So hey, join me and a lot of other developers on a wonderful journey.<br> If you access your <a href="https://www.manning.com/books/front-end-tooling-with-gulp-bower-and-yeoman/?a_aid=fettblog&amp;a_bid=238ac06a">MEAP</a> now, you get <strong>50% off</strong> with this code: <strong>mlfetool</strong>. You can read the first<br> chapter by clicking <a href="https://manning-content.s3.amazonaws.com/download/c/9612eac-ea92-4192-a4a5-fc3df4ecf29d/FET_MEAP_ch1.pdf">here</a>.</p>
